section-block.rac_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet!

section-block.rac_book_title_hed_theme_4_two-lines: The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet!
section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Carmen Agra Deedy and illustrated by Eugene Yelchin
section-block.rac_book_summary: Don Pepe, the mayor of La Paz, has banned all singing, until one day a rooster, or gallito, comes to town. He does what roosters are born to do: Sing!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Preview the books for the week, focusing on the animals in the books. Have children discuss in pairs similarities and differences.
Choose a familiar animal song like “The Farmer in the Dell” or “Six Little Ducks” to get children excited to learn more about animals and telling stories!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet! by Carmen Agra Deedy and illustrated by Eugene Yelchin.
Scout loves all books, but he especially loves narratives. They tell such interesting stories!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happened after Don Pepe made all the laws?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is happening in this picture?
What kinds of sounds did the villagers make?
What appeared in the village square? What did they say?
What happened to the teakettles after the laws were made? How did they feel?
Some left the village. What did they do as they left? Who wandered into the village?
Where did the gallito and his family roost, or stay?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happened after Don Pepe made all the laws?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The teakettles were afraid to whistle.
Some people were grateful to have a good night’s sleep.
The village was as silent as a tomb.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about telling stories.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What were the teakettles afraid to do?
The teakettles were afraid to wh_______ (whistle).
The teakettles were afraid to whistle.
How is the first law different from the last law?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help children with a different home language or culture build language skills by providing a simple sentence frame to use. For example, while pointing to the rooster, say, The rooster _____ today. Scaffold children’s responses by having them show what the rooster did, say one word, or repeat the sentence frame.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Self-Awareness
section-block.rac_body-text: When you show self-awareness, you understand what you can do and what you need help with. Discuss with a partner what each of you are good at. Tell each other what is something you would need help with. Who would you get help from?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the self-awareness Mind Builder as we reread the book, The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet! by Carmen Agra Deedy.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the story to notice the self-awareness Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to share and answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do you think all of the noise in the city made people feel? Ask a volunteer to talk about the unhappy looks on people’s faces.
What did the village do to solve their noise problem?
What did the new mayor do to make sure no one made noise? Did it work?
Some people felt grateful. Why?
What did some other people do? How did they show self-awareness? (MB)
When the rooster woke up, he did what roosters are born to do. What did the rooster do? (MB)
Even though his singing causes conflict with the mayor, what does the rooster say that he will continue to do?
The gallito knows what he needs to do. What does he know that hemust do? Who else does he sing for? (MB)
Who sings along with the rooster?

section.rac_body-text: Encourage children to use music and dance as they act out different action verbs. Give groups different cards with action verbs. Ask the children to act out first the word and then a sentence that includes that word. For instance, children might act out the word laugh and then act out the sentence, We laugh when we play. Invite children to show how they act out a word and then a sentence with the word.
Transcribe children’s speech as they tell a story that uses action words.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Emotional development is an essential aspect of growing up. Provide opportunities for children to explore self-awareness and demonstrate how to express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills. For example, have children discuss how they used to react to a situation but have matured to act in a different, more effective way. (Miller, 2019)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children to pay special attention to the important things the author tells them.

section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Not all roosters are the same, just like not all children are the same. Draw a picture of a rooster you’ve seen. How does it compare to a classmate’s rooster?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet! by Carmen Agra Deedy and illustrated by Eugene Yelchin.
Scout loves reading narrative books that tell stories.
You can think about this guiding question as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What did Don Pepe take away from the gallito?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the big book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: There are a lot of people on these pages. Do you see a crowd of people?
What are people in the crowd doing?
What was hard to do in the village?
What did Don Pepe promise?
What is he doing that shows he wants quiet? How do the people feel about being quiet? Do they like it? Why or why not?
What do you think of the new rules? Would you like to live in a place with these rules?
Why did the mayor chop down the mango tree? Was the mayor’s act of chopping the tree down right? Why or why not?
Why was the gallito in a cage? What did Don Pepe take away from him?
Did you listen and remember as we read the book today? Let’s Turn and Talk about the guiding question:
What did Don Pepe take away from the gallito?
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He took away the gallito’s home.
He took away the gallito’s corn.
He took away the gallito’s family.
He took away the gallito’s sunlight.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to tell a story using action words.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Don Pepe take away from the gallito?
Don Pepe took away the gallito’s s_______ (sunlight).
Don Pepe took away the gallito’s sunlight.
Why did the gallito keep singing?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Ask children questions that help them progress just a bit beyond what they can currently do. By carefully challenging children to go a little further in their learning, you allow them to feel a sense of growth and accomplishment without being overwhelmed. Differentiate your questions as needed to help children continue to grow and learn.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Get children excited for this lesson by talking about stories. Ask children when we tell stories and how. If no one brings it up, encourage them to think about when we tell others what we have done. For instance we might tell parents about school or might tell friends about an exciting trip that happened.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Voice in Rabbit’s House. It is a tale told on a poster.
The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet! and The Voice in Rabbit’s House each tell a story with animal characters. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What stories do we like to tell?
Let’s use pictures to help tell our stories.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Telling a Tale
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts for discussion.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who is in the house? Does Rabbit know who is in the house? How do you think Rabbit feels?
How does Leopard feel? How can you tell?
Why is Rhinoceros trembling? What does Rhinoceros think is inside the house?
What does the frog say it can do? Do you think the frog can help? Why or why not?
Why did Caterpillar tell the story of The Long Furry One? What kind of story is it?

section.rac_body-text: Have children act out the story on the Big Chart. Different children can play different animals in the story. They can show how that animal behaved in the story. If the want, they can say the words that the different animals said or they can improvise. Encourage children to be creative and let the story unfold in surprising ways. Maybe their story is different from the story on the Big Chart. That’s okay!
Invite children to tell a story about hearing a scary noise. Guide children as they write and draw in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Fluent thinking is one aspect of problem solving. Fluent thinkers are ones who can take information and see many possibilities or view objects or situations in new ways. Give children opportunities to develop fluent thinking by allowing them to brainstorm multiple answers to a single question. Remind them to turn to an adult, when necessary.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to express themselves through telling a story using music or dance. Play an upbeat song and remind children that they can dance, sing, stomp, whisper, rap, chant, or even act silly. Stop the song and note that everyone in the room is expressing themselves differently. Then finish the rest of the song, gradually reducing the volume to calm children down.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet! by Carmen Agra Deedy, but this time will be different. We will change the story and tell it in our own words!
This book is a narrative, or story. Scout loves to read story books because they often have fun characters and pictures.
This week we read a book about conflict and being true to yourself. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happened when the gallito kept singing?

section.rac_body-text: Retell and reenact the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is happening on these pages? How would you act out
this scene? Can you make the sound of engines humming?
Think about all of the noise. What do you do when something is too loud? Act out this scene.
What expression does the teakettle make to the mayor? How would you act out this expression?
Don Pepe was cranky when he saw the gallito out his window, but the gallito was merry.
What does being merry look like? What does being cranky look like? How are they different?
Look at the picture. What do you think the people looking out their windows are thinking?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to Turn and Talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happened when the gallito kept singing?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Invite children to draw or write a story about singing and making noise.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: At the end, did the people start to sing again?
The people started to s____ (sing) again.
The people started to sing again.
What happened to Don Pepe when everyone started singing at the end?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Music entertains and energizes! Music also builds language skills for children who are learning multiple languages. Through music, children can gain a better grasp of sentence structure and grammar, including the past tense. Use a familiar tune to teach children about the regular past tense.
